Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Sensing and Computing with Oscillating Chemical Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is co-funded by the Polymers Program of the Division of Materials Research and the Software and Hardware Foundations Program of the Division of Computing and Communications Foundations, with additional contributions from the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities of the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The aim of this project is to lay the foundations for new research directions in "materials that compute". To achieve this goal the work will focus on developing integrated sensing, computing and responsive systems by using non-linear oscillating chemical reactions to perform spatio-temporal processing and recognition tasks. The specific materials that will be considered for these tasks are polymer gels undergoing the oscillatory Belousov-Zhabotinsky (BZ) reaction; these materials are flexible and stimuli-responsive and encompass distinct oscillating domains. The temporal coherence of the BZ reactions in these gels will be harnessed to perform associative processing between sets of stored or learned patterns and input stimuli in the form of patterns of light, pressure, or chemistry. The effective resonance between the input patterns and the oscillators will be used as the basic computation paradigm. In effect, the aim of the studies will be to "let the physics do the computing". Hence, the research will enable the design of systems where the behavior of dynamic attractors will make possible rapid convergence to the solution. Consequently, these materials systems will respond to their environment in programmable ways. The development of these new materials systems -- which are capable of autonomously sensing, communicating, and responding to environmental changes -- will provide an opportunity for new interactions between the materials and computer science communities.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The overarching goal of this work is to transform computing platforms away from desktops or even hand-held mobile appliances fabricated from a large collection of heterogeneous parts to a computational "fabric" built with new material systems and implementing new computational paradigms. The ideal computing material would be lightweight and mechanically compliant, and would sense and respond to human touch and motion in order to perform a level of computing that will enrich the lives of its users. Furthermore, the material would perform these "sense, compute and respond" functions in a relatively autonomous manner, enabling it to operate without connections to an external power supply. This work seeks to achieve these objectives by investigating the co-evolution of energy-transducing, soft materials, such as oscillating chemical gels, and modes of computation, such as non-Boolean associative processing, which can exploit these materials characteristics. The impact of this work will be to nucleate a new field of "materials that compute"; that is, systems where the computer and the material are one and the same entity. The ability to create smart materials that can sense the environment, process information and react to complex stimuli should enable new systems that will interface with humans to provide tactile, temperature, and photonic inputs to smart clothing, robotic manipulators and possibly prosthetic limbs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The aim of this project is to lay the foundations for a  new research direction in "materials that compute". To achieve this goal, the work focused on developing integrated sensing, computing, and responsive systems by using non-linear oscillating chemical reactions to perform spatio-temporal processing and recognition tasks. The specific materials harness the self-oscillating behavior of gels undergoing the Belousov-Zhabotinsky (BZ) reaction and the electromechanical properties of piezoelectric (PZ) films. Each basic unit (i.e., oscillator) in the system encompasses a BZ gel and an overlaying PZ cantilever; the oscillations of the gel deform the PZ film and thereby generate an electric voltage. If this basic unit to connected by a wire to a second BZ-PZ unit, the generated voltage deforms the PZ cantilever and affects the oscillations of the underlying BZ gel. In this way, the oscillations of one BZ-PZ unit affects the oscillations of the other.  We focused on multiple BZ-PZ units that are interconnected to form a network of weakly coupled oscillators, which communicate and ultimately become synchronized. We utilized the synchronization of these coupled oscillators to perform basic computational tasks. In particular, the modes of synchronization represent an effective means of coding and storing information into the system. Furthermore, the resonance of the input patterns and patterns stored in the BZ-PZ network permits the system to perform pattern recognition. 

To analyze the behavior of the system, we developed a phase dynamics model to determine the modes of synchronization in this new system. On a fundamental level, the findings provide insight into the complex dynamics in weakly coupled oscillators and the factors that affect these dynamical systems. The studies also revealed how to the harness the coupled oscillators to perform pattern recognition.

Broader Impacts. There is a growing need for robotic materials that harness the intrinsic properties of the materials to perform such functionas as sensing actuation, and information storage. Ideally, these materials could be worn or readily interfaced with human activities. Because the BZ gels and PZ films are light-weight and  compliant, the BZ-PZ network could fulfil this need. Furthermore, because the BZ gels and the PZ films are responsive to mechanical deformation, the BZ-PZ systems can be used as valuable diagnostic materials. For example, the BZ-PZ gels could be inserted into gloves and used to monitor progress in a patient's ability to move their hands and fingers and thus, gauge their recovery from a hand injury. The field of designing light-weight, computational devices for human-centric activities is very much in its infancy and the advent of "materials that compute" can enable progress in this critically important area. Moreover, this work can lead to a new research discipline in computing and sensory materials engineering that can transform the quality of human life.
